description.text: Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:368375 Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=368375
This is an openScad file that produces rings in interesting patterns.
This stand works for all Apple devices that use the lightning port. Works with most cases.

Start off by designing a slanted Apple logo on any 3-D program; I used TinkerCAD.
Next, design a mount for the device. Measure with a caliper the length and width of your device.
Measure charger port distance from either side of the device with a caliper.
Make a hole within the mount for charger. Slice a rectangle in the bottom for ease.
Mount the Apple logo onto the stand.
Make any tweaks
Print!

title: Adafruit Goggle neopixel bezel and backing disc washer

description.text: While working on a Halloween costume for this year, I bought a pair of the goggles and 16 neopixels to make a mad scientist costume.  The Neopixel rings are to small and I didn't want to hot glue them in so I made up a bezel and back side that clamp the ring in with the screw on goggles and they diffuse the light quite nicely.  The Battery clip holds a 1200ma li-poly battery and a Gemma processor that I bought from Adafruit and clips on to the goggle strap.

I printed the main bezel (Goggle Disc)  in white using 2 shells and a 10% infill.  This gives you a .016 thick diffuse.  The back side I used black with the same parameters on my Makerbot 2X.  Battery clip uses 20% infill with 3 shells

author: bmsleight

description.text:
So, I got really sick of using plastic straws to hold my antennas vertical and straight. Not to mention, every time one kinked I had to go to a gas station and get a coffee mixing straw. Not only is the straw hideous and annoying, but theoretically speaking, almost any shape is better than a cylinder in terms of efficiency and aerodynamics! So, I got to work... The first few versions printed great, however in CFD software they proved to have hysteresis, at pretty much any Reynolds-number range... I switched to more of a symmetrical airfoil. Theoretical speaking, it should be more aerodynamic than a straw, or even just your straight antenna. Practically speaking, who knows how much is actually saved by using these, and who cares?? Your FPV and/or UAV airframe is going to look totally sweet with those faired antennas!
Included is the .stl for Both a large and small fairing. The small is just perfect for a DragonLink 1/2-wave vertical dipole antenna. The larger one is more universal, and with a 3mm opening it can be used on many other antennas, including (stripped) dipole video transmitter antennas.

Simply print it!
You will need to print two of them. They are 150mm long which means you need one for each 150mm long wire (Ie signal and ground)
I found best results with .1mm-.2mm layer height. Depending on ABS used you may or may not need support structure on the first few layers.
After the print, I clean them up and then use an Acetone vapor bath for about 20 minutes. It smooths out the leading edge and makes it nice and strong. My vapor bath technique is really simple, I simply found a fairly large (8-10" Diameter) HDPE container ($2 at Ace Hardware). I also found some 1/8"-1/4" wire mesh. I cut it into a square and folded the corners to act as a tray holding the parts out of the acetone. I do not use a heat bed as others do, I simply splash in some Acetone, Close the lid, give it a quick shake (seems to agitate the acetone producing extra vapor), then I open it up, place in the tray with my part, and wait! I found 20-25 minutes is perfect, not too much, and not too little. If you plan on a smoother or more-shiny product, I would suggest flipping your part periodically (every 5-10 minutes after your 20 minute mark) to keep the metal grate/mesh from leaving marks.

Designed for Zsofia Opra-Szabo’s set model for A MIDSUMMER NIGHT’S DREAM. The assembled umbrella has a diameter of approx. 10cm. (4 in.)

You will need to print 12 copies of the umbrella section to make a complete umbrella. It is possible to print all of them at once by arranging all 12 sections on the printing plate using the Makerbot software, however, on my Replicator 2 I found that there was a tendency to lose the little point at the top of each piece, which didn’t happen when the parts were printed separately.
The pieces slot together quite easily, and need to be fixed permanently into place with a few dabs of superglue. Avoid the problem of inserting the final piece into position by assembling the pieces to form two halves of the umbrella, and finish by gluing the halves together.
You can use either the straight stick or the hooked version.

I've never liked the placement of the motherboard cooling fan on the Rep1.  It pulls air from the heated build chamber and randomly blows it into the motherboard chamber.  There have been some great mods here on Thingiverse to solve this problem, but after looking at most of them, I wanted a simpler, less invasive way to better cool the motherboard.
Once I turned the printer over and looked at the situation, I quickly saw that if you just relocated the fan to the edge of the cover board it would pull air from the open area underneath the printer where it is much cooler and the fan would blow air more directly onto the motherboard. And best of all, there is minimal drilling involved, and no messing with the motherboard.
My fan was starting to go out, so I recently upgraded to an Orion fan (Digi-Key #1053-1208-ND)  It's incredibly quiet and runs at 7cfm, a tad higher than the stock 6cfm (hey, every bit helps..).  I actually replaced my extruder fans with the 6cfm version of these babies as well.  I hardly know the machine is on now - highly recommend swapping these out.  But if you don't want to buy new fans, the stock fan can be moved and used with this mod as well since it's the exact size as the Orion fan.

Parts needed:
4 - #4-40x.75 machine bolt
4 - #4-40 nut
4 - #4 washers
4 - #4 split-ring lock washers
4 - 5/32 rubber washers (optional - there isn't much vibration induced noise generated by these fans..) First, print the bracket on your printer. I printed it at 100% infill, 1 shell, .2 layer height.
Turn off, and unplug your printer.
Turn in onto the left side. Unscrew the bolt holding the motherboard cover plate to expose the board and fan.
Unbolt the fan and remove. You shouldn't need to unhook the wiring to the fan during this operation, though it might make some of the steps a little easier.
Mark the location of the fan bracket on the cover plate and drill 2 mounting holes. See photos, but I mounted mine next to the opening in the cover so it would blow air both onto the board and down the side of it into the cavity.
Mount the fan to the bracket as shown in the included pictures. Be sure and pay attention to air flow direction of the fan. It should blow towards the label side of the fan. You want the fan, once mounted, to blow into the motherboard cavity. You can use the rubber washers if you like to dampen any vibrations, but they are probably not needed. These fans run very smoothly. I didn't notice any difference if I used them or not.
Mount the fan/bracket assembly onto the cover plate and re-install the plate. You're done! I created the bracket in Autodesk 123D. I've included that file and saved it as a DXF file - not sure if this will be usable.
Note: The bracket in the photos is a version 1 prototype. I removed the inner fillet (don't know why that was there), and decreased the space between the mounting holes for the cover side to reduce interference with the fan mounting bolts.

Although I'm not going to rule out (no pun intended, I swear) the possibility of metric/english errors in lead length, if I've done my numbers and fiddling right, these should land on tenth-of-an-inch spacing. Further Note: A shortened version has been added for easier printing on the CupCake. This version is only 8cm long. Note: Skeinforge didn't like the first version of this because the Array Modifier in Blender left behind about a hundred stray internal edges! I corrected this by manually deleting them (not quite as tedious as it sounds but close) but in future I'm going to be on the lookout for a better way to manifold-ize objects that have been array-ified this way...

Took care of that. In Blender the command sequence is thus: alt-b to select offending nodes, delete, shift-select the nodes on the open space left behind one face at a time, hit f to make faces there until the design is closed up. Hit a to select all, go to mesh -
&
gt; normals -
&
gt; recalculate outside and it's good to go!

description.text:
Replacement arm for Black and Decker Workmate clamp.  ***Requires you have the handle from your original Workmate.   
I made three lengths of the handle in case the work surface has been modified and the you need a short handle to turn clear the work surface.  
Included are the Solidworks files, perhaps less than optimal;  I'd only been using the software a few weeks when I created the handle.  I have to give a shout out to Solidworks; what an incredible piece of CAD magic.

I printed two in ABS at 100% infill with 0.3mm layer height.  With raft and supports, standing upright. (Refer to pictures.)  
The simple clip STL can be used to more securely attach the handle to the new arm, as removing the handle from the broken arm tended to weaken the plastic hooks which fasten it into the arm.  
Simply insert your old handle, snap the clip in from behind, drill a 1/8" short (1/2"-3/4") pilot hole in the handle using the clip as a guide.  Install a course wood screw and tighten until the handle just spins freely as the crank is turned.   
I used a long #6 threaded screw instead of the roll pin used to attach the handle to the Workmates clamp screw, the roll pin will work but the the screw is easier and just as secure.

Mars Global Surveyor sent stuff to the PDS, The Planetary Data System. The PDS and me are acquainted. Exaggeration of 7 times makes the canyons look deep. (The 2 canyon photos are not on this globe, they are close-ups at 128 data points per degree, not 4 pt/deg). The data points are 1/4 of a degree apart for longitude and latitude.

A stable, stylized dock designed for the new LG G3. The slot in the front allows the phone to be connected to its charger (or even headphones) and still rest nicely in the dock. The concave vertical members keep the round-backed G3 from wobbling on the dock. I have also included a 2nd version that is a little more compact and allows for the USB charging cable to be routed out of the back.
Comments and Suggestions welcome!

This object will print in one piece on many medium sized printers (Makerbot Replicator, Flashforge Creator, etc.)
Arrange so the phone dock prints in the same orientation as it would sit on a desk, with supports and rafting.
0.27mm layer height and 15% infill was used for my model.

comments.text: Just as an FYI if you look at the original design that doesn't have the G3 on the back (search g3 phone holder youll see it) it comes with the little piece that fits in the hole that is in the middle, so that you don't have to futz wit the wire everytime you want to charge it.

author: tbuser

description.text:
These brackets are for mounting limit or homing switches to your Shapeoko 2 CNC.
Design goals:
1.) Most importantly: no reduction in cutting area!
2.) Use existing holes in motor plates.
3.) Use existing leftover M5 hardware.
4.) No disassembly of the axes to install parts, if possible.
5.) Mount the switches to stationary portion of each axis.
6.) Easily adjustable
Limit switches these are meant to be used with:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00H8TIEHW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
All parts are reversible, allowing you to assemble these brackets on either end of any axis.
Added a slot to the X axis bracket (not shown in pictures) that can be used for zip-tying stepper motor wires. The bracket uses a hole that I previously used for cable-tying.

They are intended to be milled from .125" G10 fiberglass which can be purchased from McMaster, ePlastics, and other vendors.
DON'T FORGET TO SET YOUR CAM SOFTWARE TO OVERCUT THE CORNERS! I have not included overcuts in the model.
Installation notes: I sized the X and Y bracket mounting holes, and the adjustment screw holes to be tapped with the M5 tap that came with your Shapeoko kit. G10 taps easily, and still allows you to turn the screws tight without stripping threads. Installation of the Z axis brackets requires removal of the 2 screws at the top of the Z axis in order to slide-in 2 insertion (tee) nuts into the makerslide (or you could get drop-in nuts). The X-axis kick-plate uses no screws and is fairly snug when installed, but I chose to use some CA glue to hold it in place better. Just be careful not to get too much CA glue in the eccentric nuts.

comments.text: well, i got them printed.  I'm taking a look at how I might install them.  Do you have any more pictures that show the bolts/nuts attaching them to the plates?  Did you have to use longer bolts to allow for the thickness of the brackets?
comments.author: lordmundi

comments.text: Added 3 more pictures showing attachment hardware.  (My machine is really dusty, just ignore that!)  I used M5 x 10 or 12 long for the X and Y brackets.  No nuts required here if you tap them as I did.  You'll need to use shorter ones for attachment of the Z bracket to the insertion nuts, I think M5x8 -- or stack washers under the head of the bolt.  All the hardware I used to attach my brackets was leftover from my build.

description.text:
In 1997 the Mars Global Surveyor measured elevations. So the 97 exaggeration factor commemorates 1997. The three photographs are not 97x they use 40x and 150x globe exaggeration factors. The blue "thingview" is the 97x design. The gray images are for a 386 megabyte .stl file linked in my About section. The Valles Marineras file is so big , I keep it on Google Drive.
Scientists credited:
S. SLAVNEY, 1999-03-10;
M. CAPLINGER, 2000-04-04;
R. SIMPSON, 2000-11-03;
The Mars Global Surveyor (MGS) spacecraft was launched from
the Cape Canaveral Air Station in Florida on 7 November 1996
aboard a Delta-2/7925 rocket. The 1062-kilogram spacecraft,
built by Lockheed Martin Astronautics, traveled nearly 750
million kilometers over the course of a 300-day cruise to
reach Mars on 12 September 1997 [JPLD-12088].
Upon reaching Mars, MGS fired its main rocket engine for a
25-minute Mars orbit insertion (MOI) burn. This maneuver
slowed the spacecraft and allowed the planet's gravity to
capture it into orbit. Initially, MGS whirled around the
red planet in a highly elliptical orbit that took 45 hours
to complete.
Thank you NASA.

Here is a link to all data that I used for Mars:
http://pds-geosciences.wustl.edu/mgs/mgs-m-mola-5-megdr-l3-v1/mgsl_300x/meg004/
It has 4 files of Mars elevations, and instructions about format.

Please visit (http://hackaday.io/project/2068-%2460-bluetooth-head-mounted-display.-) for additional details.
The OLED display is a small .96" display controlled by an arduino nano board. The display receives text and commands from a HC-05 serial bluetooth module connected to the arduino. There is also a small speaker and RGB LED connected to the board. The OLED display, RGB LED, and speaker are all controllable over bluetooth. The device is powered by a adafruit powerboost module connected to a small 0.7Wh lipo battery. The optics are a small mirrored right angle prism and a magnifying lense. The frame and casing is all 3D printed with ABS using a solidoodle 2 pro printer. The Arduino communicates with the oled display using i2c (inter-integrated circuit). The RGB LED and the speaker use the arduino's digital output pins. The display is controlled over bluetooth using a application running on an Android phone or Linux terminal. The glasses are very portable and foldable.
Total cost ~$60. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9quvlhMxEEs

title: Zero-Backlash Magnetic Ball Joint Rod Ends

description.text:
These are designed to work with 3/8" balls, 0.230" diameter carbon fiber rods, and N50 cylindrical magnets which are 10mm in diameter and 15m high.
Description
This can be printed with a layer height of 0.2mm or 0.1mm. I use 0.2mm. Use a shell thickness of 2mm or four layers, so that all of the walls will be printed with concentric circles, instead of back-and-forth infill. I use a 3/8" ball end mill to gently clean out the ball bearing sockets. Note: I have to print out two to four of these at a time, to get the correct dimensions. I use these with my magnetic effector: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/kossel-plus-magnetic-effector And magnetic carriages: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/kossel-plus-magnetic-carriage--2 Contact [email protected] if you need an inexpensive source for the ball studs or magnets.

Get a pair of 3/8" ball bearings (or you can use a pair of my ball studs), and make a jig which you will use to make the resulting rods all be exactly the same length. The distance between the two ends of your jig should be should be 9.5mm+DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD. 9.5mm is the diameter of a 3/8" ball bearing, and since your jig will have two of them inside it, subtracting the size of the extra half on one end and the extra half on the other end, will yield exactly DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD. Nice, eh? Dry fit the parts together. I get my strong walled 0.230" tubing from TriDPrinting.com or Goodwinds.com. Mix up some 5-minute epoxy and glue first one end, and then the other, and then make sure it fits perfectly in your jig, while you let the glue harden. BTW, I sell these sized for a full-size Kossel/Delta printer (288mm from the center of one ball bearing to the center of the other) for $60/set of six, complete with ball studs. I use a large micrometer to precisely measure the arms and write the lengths on them. Here is a link to a page where I describe installing them and calibrating a Kossel Clear: http://www.maui-3d.com/kcZeroBacklashInstallation.php Note: If you use Rich Cattell's version of Marlin, and you accurately know the length of DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD, you can use the "G30 A Dnnn" command to calibrate your printer in about 10 minutes. On my first printer, I spent a week trying to get it calibrated by hand, and finally gave up when it was "close enough"!

comments.text: Hi, Can you tell us where you found the magnetic ball and socket joints ? Or how do you manufacture (glue, solder) ?
comments.author: CherHubert

comments.text: I sell the ball studs for $1, so $12 for a set of 12, plus $4 for US air mail postage.

This fan shroud for 120mm fans is ideal for blasting a fast horizontal stream of collimated air over your delicate prints. It is meant to replace hotend-mounted fans, particularly on small printers that are unable to carry such accessories. For example, the RepRapPro Huxley. Adding a larger and more powerful 120mm fan will greatly increase results and eliminate the need for a second opposing fan. I use the 225DS-1LP13, manufactured by Etri. For mounting options, check out my vitamin-free fan mounts: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:36300 This shroud is derived from animator75's fan shroud which comparatively has a wider and less efficient air flow: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:290141
Observe images above for proper shroud positioning.

This thing is a 3D printed Dobsonian telescope designed for an 8" primary mirror with a focal length of 48". The optical tube assembly consists of aluminum extrusions attached with 3D printed ribs designed for standard hardware and covered with cardboard tubing. The optical tube was mounted onto a base that was made from 3/4" baltic birch plywood cut on a CNC router. The bottom base plates are separated with plastic bearings to allow for control.
  • Rack-and-Pinion Focuser: Orion Telescopes Item #13031
  • Finder Scope and Bracket: Orion Telescopes Item #07222
  • Spider Cell: E-Scopes
  • Mirror Set (8 inch f/6 primary with elliptical secondary): E-scopes
  • Mirror Cell: University Optics
  • Aluminum Extrusions: McMaster Carr Item #07222
  • Ball Bearings: McMaster Carr Item #9587K13
  • Cardboard Tubing: Menards Item #SONCOM10x12FT
  • Plywoord: D&D Plywood
    Parts were printed on a MakerBot Replicator 2 (4th Generation).

title: The Tudor Rose Box (with secret lock)

description.text:
My latest design and back to my English roots.. I call it the Tudor Rose box. I have tried to create an effect of heavy wood carving that was popular during the Tudor period.
This was a real challenge.
The box also has a secret lock:-)
PLEASE NOTE THE FOLLOWING CHANGES:
Some slicers were having problems with the vines which were very thin and missing them out. I have uploaded two additional version of the box body and the front slider panel which have thicker vines.
box_body_thicker_vines.stl
front_slider_panel_thicker_vines.stl
Please use these if you are experiencing problems with the older files.
I have uploaded an additional STL for the rose which should slice much better than the original.
I have written some detailed instruction on how to assemble this model. http://www.instructables.com/id/The-Tudor-Rose-Box-Assembly-Instructions/

comments.text: I avoid the fumes of acetone by using Fructis brand hair spray on my heatbed.  For each new build I rough the old sprayed surface with a straight edge utility blade and add a quick spray  to refresh the surface.  I can do over a dozen builds before having to wash it off with water.  Builds pop right off after they have cooled.  I keep my bed at 100 C.

comments.text: From my experience, hairspray works well with PLA on cold or warm beds. Fro ABS, you'll need something like Elmer's glue and a heated bed.

comments.text: I use fine settings and a lot of stuff I print is 12 hrs. The box on this was over 6 hrs but I used 100% fill and .15 layers. I use ABS and found that putting down the wide blue painters tape, then roughing it up with 3M P220 sand paper (sometimes I just use wire brush), then wiping down with acetone makes parts stick like crazy (no more glue).

comments.text: Oh and your automata are fabulous and something I am working towards (or trying to). Automata are a passion of mine: I really like the examples you see from 18th and 19th centuries - very clever designs and artistically beautiful as well.  I think if you can create a story around a mechanism through presentation, then people start to project their own ideas on it and it makes the model more complete. The Tudor Rose box started out as a very plain box with a sliding mechanism and a hinge which prints assembled.  Once I had the "working parts" functioning, I then went on to develop the art. With that, I think it becomes more than just a locking box.  Of course, sometimes you change the mechanisms to suit the art and the idea.

comments.text: I haven't tried to slice it using Skeinforge.  I've used Slic3r and KISS - both which had different ways of handling the petals.  Translating a Tudor rose to 3D is interesting because they are generally only seen in 2D.  The petals, while very flat are still curved up and slightly over at the tip - which is what gives them their characteristic look.  It took me a while to get this looking right in Maya (although you could use Blender too), but they are an odd shape for anything to slice and print.  As an experiment, why not try a different slicer with a single rose? If you do, I'd be interested to see the results.

This is a Mid / High power rocket made from a PDF someone posted on a rocket forum: http://www.rocketryforum.com/showthread.php?59964-Offering-up-a-Scratch-Design There are two fincans, one for a 54mm motor, and one for a 38mm motor. I had to add a significant amount of weight to the nosecone to get the balance right with either configuration. Launched successfully with a Gorilla Rocket Motors H225 Black Lightning: http://www.gorillarocketmotors.com/reloads.html

comments.text: I think it would be good to add the support material (or set this up to not need support) necessary to print on a wider variety of printers.  For example, I would split the fincan(s) and nose cone in half so that the overhangs are minimized and they can print in parts.  I might try it and see....

title: AOC I2367F &  I2757FM VESA Adaptor Pole mount

description.text:
Aoc Monitor stand adapter to give a vesa mounting option where there otherwise wasn't one.  
This mount will possibly work with all the monitors within this series, check by printing a paper copy first.

comments.text: Thank you for the help. I made a print today and it came out excellent, mounted my AOC I2367F without any difficulty. When printed on paper dimensions were a bit off standard VESA spec (I used default windows 10 app - 3D builder) but in real it came out all good. However a small thing I noticed is that if you are using 100mm VESA type and you intent to rotate/up-down display and you are using HDMI connector  - the rear side of the connector is going to edge on the mount (I had to chip of a bit to over come this). It will be good idea to extent the hollow cuts on the sides towards the screw hole bit further.

Spool holder for RigidBot, uses a dozen 5/16" ball bearings* (or slingshot ammo). Attach the lower screw before attaching the spool holder. Make sure you test the strength of your print before using it. You'll want it to be strong enough that a tangled spool won't get pulled off and drop on the printer. There are two versions, the thinner one is designed to be small enough to fit the small Taulman spools, the thicker one will be stronger. I use one of each on my printer. You can use it with this filament guide to make the filament unspool consistently. There are several internal support ribs so it should be stronger than it looks, as long as you get decent layer adhesion. *affiliate link

Unearthly Products Division is happy to deliver: The Inverted Seafloor Globe. The Earth's ocean floor is raised up instead of being sunk down. The 3D model shows the deep trenches as peaks. For example, in the first photograph, at the lower left side, peaks are seen for the deep Tonga Trench. The elevations are reversed so that trench rises up to become tall peaks. ETOPO2 database. Exaggerated 350x for elevations. The land is smooth and sunk down lower than the sea.
What if your world were turned upside down? A new video game lets you find out. Buy "Planet Smasher" today! Lay waste to continents. Upturn tectonic plates. This is big. Materials science is illustrated by using tungsten in a giant's factory. Huge tools smash the planets. H-Bombs move crust. Originator: National Geophysical Data Center (NGDC)

Global Digital Elevation Model (ETOPO2) represents gridded (2 minute by 2 minute) elevation and bathymetry for the world. These data were derived from the National Geophysical Data Center (NGDC) ETOPO2 Global 2' Elevations data set from September 2001.

{

}

{
if ($filtered_surface[$row][$col] < $flood )
{

}
$x= $pixel_width$col;

description.text: My dad designed this impossible dovetail joint. It prints well with 0.3mm layers down to 0.5 scale. 0.25 works with some manual trimming.

I recommend printing in the default orientation (lengthwise ) - it will make the pieces slide together smoothly due to the grain of the material. If you print the pieces flat they will snap together snugly and be difficult to remove.  
If you print in the default orientation consider adding a 3mm brim.  
It's a pretty fun desk gadget when printed at full size.

remixed_from.author: Brendan22
remixed_from.title: T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 Drone (5 inch props)

title: T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 Drone (7-8 inch props)

description.text:
This quadcopter is about 22mm longer and 2mm taller than the popular T4 Quadcopter Mini 250. It supports up to 8" props and a 2200mah 3S battery. Check out the whole "T" copter family:
  • TX8 Octocopter
  • T6 Hexacopter
  • T4 Quadcopter (10" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 315 (7-8" props)
  • T4 Quadcopter Mini 250 (5" props)
  • Tubular Crossfire 2 quadcopter
    I've added a post on the forums over at DIY Drones for discussing and improving these designs.

    Videos

  • Build video playlist
  • Build video 1: Body assembly
  • Build video 2: Install motors
  • Build video 3: ESCs and power
  • Build video 4: Flight control
  • Frame strength testing
  • First flight

    Features:

  • completely 3D printable (without support)
  • fully assembled frame weight less than 130 grams!
  • strong, simple assembly with no bolts to save weight! Everything is secured using 2.5mm zip ties.
  • includes two arm options - 28mm, and 30mm motor cup (inside diameter). The 30mm cup has slots for 3mm motor bolts (the other is 2mm).
  • strong braced tube section arms with plenty of room to conceal motor wiring
  • designed for a 3S battery (up to 2200) located right in the centre of rotation/thrust (110 x 38 x 24mm capacity).
  • plenty of space to mount ESCs - concealed but still well ventilated for cooling.
  • top plate has space for a variety of flight controllers and a Mobius style camera. It also features 3mm mounting holes so stand-offs could be used to add an additional deck of components. Alternatively two hex holes are available to add 3D printed posts and rear upper deck.
  • RF "invisible" frame - as opposed to carbon fiber or aluminium
  • Sketchup file included so you can make changes to suit yourself

    Revision History

    2 September 2014
    Legs for your T4 Mini are now available.
    31 August 2014
    Version 1.3
    Added a bridge to T4Mini315VibrationFloatingPlate.stl to make it less flexible. No other files were changed.
    15 August 2014
    Version 1.2
    New vibration isolating top plate option. This option is compatible with previous body and all other components. It replaces the top plate with one that has mounting points for 65 gram vibration damping balls that then connect to a new floating plate to hold your flight controller and camera.
    New files:

  • T4Mini315VibrationTopPlate.stl
  • T4Mini315VibrationFloatingPlate.stl
    30 July 2014 - Version 1.01
  • there seem to be a lot more 8" prop options so I've added two arms to suit 8" props (28mm cup and 30mm cup).
  • extended the 7" arms by 5mm to give a bit more clearance from the body.
  • modified the body to raise the arm sockets so there is a bit for material in the bottom of the socket - stronger to support longer arms.

I printed all parts in PLA, 0.25mm layers with 40% infill, 2 shells and 3 top/bottom layers. Feel free to experiment. I didn't play around too much with the settings as these gave me a good strong result.
Fitting the top plate and bottom tray
Both the top plate and bottom tray are designed to slide from front to back (at 45 degrees) as they are being fitted into the body. In particular the top plate needs to be pressed firmly down onto the 8 angled guides as you slide it back. Once in place the top plate will clip onto the smaller bumps near the rear cable tie mount (just above the rear arms). Look closely at the parts and it will all become clear.
Calibration test
T4MiniTestSocket.stl contains a cut-down socket you can use for testing the fit of your arms before committing to the full Body print.
A quick word about scaling
According to Wikipedia apparently "there is no scale information [in STL files], and the units are arbitrary". There is often confusion with STL files and metric versus imperial (inches) units. I designed these parts in Sketchup using metric units and they import correctly into my slicer (which is also set to metric). If you have issues, check your application to see if has a way to select metric or alternatively scale down by a factor of 25.4.
Also, the Sketchup file contents are scaled up by 1000 (attempt to solve some Sketchup quirks). I scale each component down by 0.001 before exporting the STL so they are in real millimetre sizes.

• 4 arms (9 grams, 0.5 hour print each*)
  • 1 body (40 grams, 2.75 hour print*)
  • 1 top plate (12 grams, 1 hour print*)
  • 1 bottom tray (14 grams, 1 hour print*)
  • 1 battery pin (almost nothing, real fast)
  • 2 posts (optional)
  • 1 post plate (optional)
    *times were recorded on my Makergear M2 printer which has a 0.35mm nozzle and was printing at 4500mm/min.
    ...and "hardware"...
  • 2,5mm (wide) zip ties (approx 100mm long)
  • some foam for padding the battery compartments. I ended up using self adhesive window draft-stop tape from my local DIY store.
  • some Kyosho Zeal Gel or similar anti-vibration gel and rubber bands for mounting the flight controller and camera.
  • double sided adhesive foam tape (for mounting other electronics)
  • soldering gear and connectors to suit your electrical bits
    • If your new to RC copters then the ArduCopter wiki is a great place to find out everything you need know.

author: savageevan

title: Printrbot Simple Tower ziptie board enclosure

description.text:
If you're like me you thought the board was just a little too close to the moving parts and also impossible to access the micro sd card slot!  I had problems with ribbing caused by the Z axis clamp hitting cables constantly, this helped!
I had cut open the side of the Simple Tower add on, but if you don't have the tower, anything before where the board was mounted to under the machine should be just fine with this.  The slots on the case are to secure the case with zipties at their normal points on these machines (2013, 1401, early/modded/upgraded 1405). but this could probably be used to mount it most anywhere with zipties.  You can print with support to catch the overhangs but I didn't need to, turning the fan on a little before it got to that part was just fine.
Made a deeper version to clear some of the connectors, especially the power connector.
The cutout of the logo isn't exactly over the silkscreen.  I'm not sure if this is because of my slicing or something else.

author: IvanFjodorovich

description.text:
Wheel for the track of an older Maytag Dishwasher. The Model number for the dish washer is MDC4000AWX,
Now getting close to 20 years old it out lasted the marriage for which it was a gift. A dish washer from back when there was a Maytag repair man sitting around with nothing to fix. Its a dishwasher where you can put an un-rinsed Pyrex lasagna pan in and it comes out spotless along with the rest of the load.
Divorced I am, but my dishes are as clean as ever without the bother of a wife.
Its only problem was a hose coupling leak due to the rubber breaking down. After the wheel broke, and the glue fix failed after 2 years... Its with pride I extended its life with the gift of a new wheel. Included is the STL and the Solidworks file for those who have a real CAD program.

Print in ABS to withstand the heat. I printed it at 100%, resolution of 0.3 mm with raft and full support.
After cleanup, I sealed and hardened by applying a coat of ABS Primer (found in plumbing section of most any good hardware store) but Acetone works about as well.
You should/will have to drill out the hole for a better fit. Be sure to apply a coat or two of the primer inside the wheels bore/hole to harden the ABS and give it better wear properties.

comments.author: Nicoteen66

comments.text:
On mine, not silicon, the old copper type of board, but the principle should be the same.
I connect the outputs from the control board (your ramp board) to the relay control side, the copper heat bed, is connected to a seperate power supply, the +ve side passing through the relay output side. I thought the ramp board mosfet would be able to control and handle the current requirements of a silicon heat bed, and hence no need for a relay control.
Hope this helps a bit.

remixed_from.author: elk
remixed_from.title: Iron-on 3D printed artworks - Proof of concept

description.text:
Works with ABS.
After going through the wash, the sharper corners can get nicked off and thinner isthmuses can develop cracks.
Rounded, convex areas are awesomely robust.
I'm sure printing a thinner decal than the relatively thick one shown here would further improve results.

1) Generate a decal
For all you other blender scripting users out there, I'm including the simple python script I used while creating this test decal from a svg. Invoke it like:
svg="import.svg" stl="output.stl" ./blender -P blender_decaler.py
Any thin model will work, just make it as thin as your printer is calibrated to print 2) Put some wax paper on your HBP. The wax will melt and adhere to the bottom just enough so that you don't have to clip it down for short prints. (If you try to print anything taller, you'll have to tension it down!) 3) Print your decal. I've gotten some pretty awesome surface quality as the wax paper peels right off, but surface quality doesn't matter... we're going to remelt it in a second.... 4) Place wax paper on ironing board, put decal on top, then place fabric on top. ONLY USE 100% COTTON! Poly and elastine were not so good >_< 5) Heat a cast-iron frying pan on your stove, then use that to iron it down. Keep going until you smell the ABS melt. 6) Wear and wash until it gets damaged, re-ironing will fix most problems!

description.text:
The many cases and mounts for the standard LCD display, are too big to be printed on the metal simples 150mm bed, which is not surprising since the physical size of the board (Sain Smart version) is 150mm wide.
So I created this mount plate with four corner posts to screw the display too, and an angled bracket that must be glued to the plate. The angled bracket uses a pair of 10mm neodynium magnets (press fit into bracket) to attach the display to the base of the printer.
Since the printrbot requires a custom cable to use the standard display, I am including my notes (another picture) on the wiring hookup for that cable

author: joehart

description.text:
Spherical drone
=
Hi, here is the final year project I realized during my engineering school at Polytech' Tours. This drone is designed to answer the problems drones encounter with collisions (ie. crash, bam and boom!), and to be able to roll on the floor/wall/roof.

How it works (mechanics):

  • The sphere's shape is a truncated icosahedron, just the same shape as a football ball (well, soccer ball for our american friends ^^). It is mounted on two hoop, oriented 90° each, making the whole thing a gimball. This gimball allows the sphere to rotate almost freely around the drone chassis.
    The two hoops are composed of :

    1. Jonction_petit_bouclier (or grand)
    2. Quart_pertit_bouclier (or grand)
      while only the joints on the sphere are printed. The rest of the sphere is made of 3mm carbon fiber rod (approximately 6 meters total), available at decathlon in the kite aisle.

      You'll need :

  • 50 x Croisillons_Y3_Bouclier
  • 10 x Croisillions_Y4_Bouclier
  • 2 x Croisillions_étoile5_Bouclier

    About Carbon rods, you'll need to cut :

  • 10 x 55mm rods to link the Croisillions_étoile5_Bouclier to the Croisillions_Y4_Bouclier on top and bottom of the sphere.
  • 90 x 66.5mm carbon rods to connect Croisillons_Y3_Bouclier to each others.

    Chassis and hoops

    For the structure inside the shield (Plaque_Centrale with Connecteurs, support_moteur and the two hoops) you'll need 46 M3x12 screws (maybe some longer ones will be needed).

    You'll want to print :

  • 1 x Plaque_Centrale
  • 1 x Support_Moteur
  • 2 x Plaque_Centrale_Connecteur
  • 4 x Quart_pertit_bouclier
  • 4 x Jonction_Quart_pertit_bouclier
  • 4 x Quart_Grand_bouclier
  • 4 x Jonction_Quart_Grand_bouclier
  • 2 x Palette_Guignole (either plein or fly_wing like)
    Software implementation

    The project used a MultiWii AIOP as flight controller, but the MultiWii implementation of the "DualCopter" is not behaving correctly, so I lacked some time to complete the project. I can provide the MultiWii project, where everything was configured, but not functional (the only tricky thing was to change the orientation of the plane in order to fit the mounting orientation).
    Page is still under construction, please be patient :)

comments.author: fma

comments.text:
Hi,
The up down is controller by the amount of power given to the motors (this one is obvious I know ^^)
The Yaw is controller by slowing down a motor, while accelerating the other one (then the torque will do the job)
The Pitch and Roll are done the same way each other : You can see some vertical governs on the bottom, driven by a servo each, which will deflect the air flow from the engine, and bank the drone in the chosen direction.
Hope this is clear enough, I'll be able to get the hand back on this drone soon, with a CC3D running OpenPilot, then i'll probably be able to post a Video of it flying!! :)

title: Blue2 Racer..  Lowpoly up.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Inspired by my drawing: http://yzorg.deviantart.com/art/Blue-2-70195139
5th element, or the Immortal film...
A lowpoly upload.. high poly only on PM request.
The turbines are coming later and seperate.. (last pic)
for optimal print orientation. i need to testprint them first.
Feel free to implement the car in any game of yours.
just give me my credits.

Printed in symetrical halves. directly used slicer software cura for this... Coating process:
i used two coats of 2K Carpaintfiller. (poliurethane.. comes in spraycan)
This stuff can add up to 2mm of coat thickness.. so printlines vanish pretty fast. but it can eat your details. For glueing a thick epoxy paste was used.. after first overall sanding (180-240grit).
then i went on to sand all over with 320grit and 500grit. (depending on quality of your sanding paper you need to use water for sanding)
i should have put more effort in sanding..
After the sanding.. get the dust off. Generally important for Paintjobs:
Make shure no Oilspray-myst (like WD40 or PTFE spray) has been in the same room... this can severly lower the quality of your paintcoats. For best metallic effect adding about 2-3 as-light-as-possible coats of your chrome or silver(this makes shure the reflecting microparticles in the paint will lay flat on the surface.. they wont if you ad thick coats.
after that tint everything with a translucent ink colour. For the intense glossyness i used a 2K glossy varnish spraycan. here i make thick coats about 2-3 layers. ..
But Attention.. if you spray glossy varnish over a metallic effect paint it will get dull and ugly.

author: yzorg

description.text:
Making tea takes some time and space. This caddy lets you bring what you need to the table, easy chair, or patio, where you can make your brew at your own pace. When you're done, it also gives you a place to put the used teabag, sugar envelopes, and other detritus so they don't make a mess or blow away.
The bottom sports a round anchor that fits snugly into your cup or mug, so you can carry both cup and caddy in one hand.

(1) Print 2 items, the tea caddy itself, and one of the discs to suit your cup or mug (large is 77mm, small is 70 mm). Clean up the prints as desired. Note: I printed mine in ABS then put it in an acetone fume chamber to smooth the surfaces for a clean look.
(2) Glue your selected disc to the bottom of the tea caddy. It's a low-stress joint, so anything will work: ABS cement (if you printed in ABS) or epoxy work nicely.
(3) Stock with tea stuff and enjoy!

description.text: A model of the Local Motors Rally Fighter Body.  The Rally Fighter is the world's first co-created production vehicle; a 50 state street legal, 430 HP off-road racing machine.  For more information, visit www.rallyfighter.com

We have been successful printing this on our Replicator 2 with support structure at the default medium resolution setting in Makerware. High resolution seems to lead to a support structure that is very difficult to remove.  
The largest model printed to date was wrapped in the same Vinyl used on the full size Rally Fighter, and was then affixed to a Nikko 1/16 scale drift car. Future plans include printing in multiple pieces to achieve bigger size bodies, with the intent of converting a Traxxas trophy truck to a scale Rally Fighter.

description.text: Object was made during an intro to 3d printing class taught by Chris Ready and Jeffrey Wood of Makesalot guest teaching at the Austin Tinkering School.

This quadrangle from the US Geological Survey is called Castle Rock Ridge. The town of Boulder Creek is in a valley in this 3D model. The database is called SDTS, the Spatial Data Transfer Standard. This has 30 meter data point spacing. If you want a 3D model of a quad that you like more than this one, it will cost you. There is also a 10 meter SDTS database.
The ThingView shows a blue simulation where the flatlands at top right are in Los Gatos, California and the valley pointing into the bottom left is the San Lorenzo River Valley with Boulder Creek.
The gray image is the quad from a lower angle.
The SDTS files were input to my Perl program and out pops an stl file!

description.header: Populate the California terrain heights into the surface array
description.text:
open(INFILE, "$height_file_in") or die "Can't open $height_file_in: $!";
while ($line=)
{
@height = split(/s+/,$line,13);
$row = $row_max - (int(($height[1] - $lat_start)/$meters));
$column = int(($height[0] - $lon_start)/$meters);
$filtered_surface[$column][$row] = $surface[$column][$row] + $exag*$height[2];
}
You can get SDTS data files for each USA state here:
http://store.geocomm.com/data/state/ close(INFILE);

title: Just another CNC mill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In progress.....
Just collecting and put together knowledge to get my own CNC mill.
Really need one but cannot afford to buy one off the shelf.
Project will go in slowspeed.
At last, all hw arrived uppdated a pic with the frame so now the work will begin still in slowspeed.
The main mechanic things in place got some dear help from my friend Nils-Åke Stenström and got a spot in his garage to fullfill my mechanic work.
Update:
Had to redesign the board and replace all moving mechanic parts with 12mm rods and bearings ( http://www.ebay.com/itm/12pcs-LM12UU-12mm-Linear-Ball-Bearing-Bush-Bushing-/290757462821? ). The step motors were to heavy ( Nema 17 ). So i simply took the K8200 plastic kit ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:203292 ) and redesigned some parts. Bearing X-Clamp.stl used as is rescaled in repitier host to 1.15 to fit 12mm rod.

First I needed a library with hex shapes and one with i.e.stepper motors.
Found 2 that i liked:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6021
https://github.com/elmom/MCAD
Than some frame-inspiration ( after many back and forth I decided pipes ) by Tom McGuire
http://www.instructables.com/id/Easy-to-Build-Desk-Top-3-Axis-CNC-Milling-Machine/?ALLSTEPS
I wanted an other controller card and decided this kit.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/DE-Ship-4Axis-Nema23-Stepper-Motor-287oz-in-Driver-CNC-Milling-Machine-/200911491410?pt=UK_BOI_Industrial_Automation_Control_ET&hash=item2ec7421152
There are errors in the manual like the pinout and inverted pin 17 that comes with the kit as I have confirmed discovered by:
http://reprap.org/wiki/4_Axis_TB6560_CNC_Stepper_Motor_Driver_Board_Controller
So a test of motors and controller cards are nessesery time to clame errors to the distributor are 14 days.
Still waiting a lot of parts so I starts with the feet and will come back to you later.
Frameparts delivered from Comfortbutiken in Visby
http://www.comfortvisby.se
Contact Jonas Gustavsson, contact info on their site.
They deliver frames in sizes you like.

title: RoboG, gimbal, stabilizzatore video standalone per Sony as15 e gopro2/3

description.text:
....IlRoboG è un gimbal standalone,uno stabilizzatore video a mano pronto all' uso progettato per le sony As 15 e le gopro2 e 3.
Il suo uso permette di fare delle riprese video a mano stabilizzate anche in situazioni al limite, per esempio correndo con la camera in mano. Con questo
stabilizzatore si può dire addio al "mal di mare" nel guardare i video, i video risulteranno fermi sull' orizzonte azzerando le alterazioni nel video anche dei movimenti più repentini,
sembrerà come se la camera fosse carellata su binari.
Inoltre con il RoboG si può manualmente attraverso il joystick modificare l' inclinazione della camera in modo da seguire il soggetto ripreso in movimento a differenti altezze.
Il tutto è progettato per essere stampato in abs con stampante 3d.
Il progetto parte da un nucleo di base che è il gimbal per multirotori, composto da questi elementi:
RG-gomm.3mm.V1
RG-mot.roll-gomm4mm
RG-mot.roll.V1
RG-Cmot.picht
a seconda se si usi la gopro o la sony questi i componenti da affiancare x il gimbal x multirotori.
X le sony:
RG-case. sony V1
RG-sonyins.Mot.V1
X le gopro 2 e 3:
Box.gopro3-corpoA
La sucessiva evoluzione per un uso a mano o su mezzi di trasporto terreni è costituita da un blocco centrale a cui si ancora l' attacco della maniglia x un uso a mano oppure le due ventose x farlo aderire a qualsiasi piano liscio(carrozzeria, carenature moto ect.)
il blocco centrale è composto dai seguenti pezzi:
RG-joystick.cop.V1-6
RG-joystick. base V1.6.5
RG-corpo.centr.V1.1
RG-copri.scheda.V1.2
infine i due moduli x l' uso a mano o su ventosa:
per il manico da bicicletta ho disegnato due supporti che vano infilati nel tubo di carbonio e fissati con vite passante dal manico fino al tubo
RG-supp-manig.V1
per le ventose ho disegnato questi supporti:
RG-supp.vent.V1.1
Inoltre visto che sia la sony che la gopro3 hanno il wi-fi che permette di visionare le riuprese in realtime, ho disegnato un supporto x ancorare al tubo di carbonio un porta cellulare:
RG-portaCell.V1.6.5
sia il manico da bicicletta, le ventose che il portacellulare li ho acquistati in negozi da 99 cents.
nella sezione file ho messo un file pdf di istruzioni per il montaggio

description.text:
Choose any text you want to make a pencil holder or letter sculpture. UPDATE: coming soon: can calculate spacing for each letter pair based on the letter widths, so it doesn't have to be done manually. This is an easier to use and more general design than my previous pencil holders. It's strangely pleasing to have little word sculptures.
To fit standard pencils, scale the Z-height to 11 mm before printing the .stl.file. See Instructions for some tips on customizing. BrandonW6 had a similar idea for a 3D text pen last year:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45576
It's quite nice, with a different, retro font, upper and lower case, and spaces allowed between letters.
And whpthomas improved it for Bic pens and added a cap:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:148722/

Using Maker Desktop Beta 3.2, targeting a Replicator (Dual) device, and printing on a Flashforge Creator, scaling to 11 mm for the Z-height is about right for many 6-sided pencils.
Can be printed without a raft. Though you can use Thingiverse's nice Customizer interface, it's easier to visualize customizations if you download TEXTpencil.scad and open it with OpenSCAD, an application that you can install for free.
http://www.openscad.org/downloads.html
Especially for longer words, setting the right spacings for each letter gets a bit tedious. Set the variables show_pencil = 1, show_hole = 0 so you can quickly see your customizations with by pressing F5. When you are happy with your design, set the variables back to no pencil and show hole, check that it looks OK by pressing F6, then export from OpenSCAD into a .stl file, and import that file into Makerbot or whatever 3D printing tool you use.

Replacement for the standard valve cap on a bicycle, bike or car. There are 2 stl files:
  • Presta/French valve (standard bicycle valve)
  • Schrader valve (motor vehicle type valve)
    • Thinkercad files can be found here:
  • https://tinkercad.com/things/lBwqNIsL6Dk-stormtrooper-valve-cap-presta
  • https://tinkercad.com/things/h4u41WKWXBE-stormtrooper-valve-cap-schrader-car

Print with:
  • 0 shells
  • 50% infill
    • I've printed it with support but without a raft. There is no built-in thread.
    Try to screw it on the valve with a little force or use a tap tool to add a thread.

title: Printable tatting shuttle
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A tatting shuttle is a simple equipment for winding and guiding thread. Series of knots are making a beautiful shape.
This shuttle has a pointed tip for convenience.
I painted several shuttles to make mine unique. Make your own!

  • UPDATE: I added a THICKER SHARK version, as well as separated parts version. the original model was often printed with a cavity inside the pointed tip of the shark, which weakens the durability.

  • [email protected]: I added fillets for the center column, which relieve the stress of the plate. Also, there is "big" version for bigger tatting piece.

Print it with raft and full support is recommended.
Sand a tip to make a sharp point.
